formal_terms.description: A common weed named after former president who was in power when weed spread in early 1970s
Twi terminology for the end of the cropping period and the sart of the fallow period
A climbing weed - vein on spiders backside
Used to describe a soil when it has had a long fallow, under nfofoa kwae. Considered fertile.
Large rock in soil that is not ironstone
The common intercrop mix of maize planted only in the first year, followed by cocoyam, cassava and plantain in the same year. Often planted when establishing Cocoa.
the twi terminology for this is: asase ahooden asa, literal translation: soil power is finished
A forest that has never been cleared for cropping.
indicator of soil fertility. Originally thought to be Mimosa pudica (sensitive plant) but this is unlikely if it is an indicator of soil fertility - Piper umbellatum is more likely.
A land type that may refer to a mature forest that was cleared in the past, an old cocoa farm, or forest thicket type vegetation.
a general name for a bad weed
general name for a bad or problem weed
A creeping weed found after clearing nfofoa kwae.  Momordica balsamina, M. charantia (Cucurbitaceace)
a weed and a fruit tree
a weed literal translation of name is 'pull and fart' twi - pull ta-fart

memos.content: Women farmers discussing different weed species

Livelihoods of indigenous people at Gogoikrom  Farming is the major source of income. Cash is obtained mainly from the sale of cocoa, maize, plantain, cocoyam and cassava. Rice received as part of sharecropping arrangements with settlers is also sold.  Cocoa is the most important crop at Gogoikrom. Food crops are intercropped during the establishment of cocoa and include cocoyam, plantain, cassava and maize. Many people are absentee landlords who live in Kumasi. Land is either own land or sharecropped. Sharecropping is considered a lucrative means of obtaining an asset - a cocoa farm, by the indigenous population as well as by settlers.   Key to letters used on the diagrams denoting means of land acquisition:                                            O - land that is owned or land that a family has traditional usufactory rights over  S - sharecropping F - land that is cropped at no charge to the tenant through a friendly relationship with a landlord or relative   R - rented land

Livelihoods of indigenous people at Gogoikrom  Cocoa is the most important crop at Gogoikrom. Food crops are intercropped during the establishment of cocoa and include cocoyam, plantain, cassava and maize. Rice is grown on lowland areas as a cash crop. Vegetables are also cultivated for sale but are less extensive. Sharecropping is less common than the use of own land.

Livelihoods of settler people at Gogoikrom  Cocoa is also the most important crop for settlers. However settlers also farm rice in lowland areas and vegetables as cash crops. The majority of land obtained by settler farmers is under a sharecropping arrangement, particularly for cocoa.  Key to letters used on the diagrams denoting means of land acquisition:                                            O - land that is owned or land that a family has traditional usufactory rights over                          S - sharecropping F - land that is cropped at no charge to the tenant through a friendly relationship with a landlord or relative   R - rented land

content: Farmers' knowledge of soil fertility and weed management in Atwima district, Ghana
Soil fertility management,  soil classification,  weed management and  cocoa shade trees.
This knowledge base was originally created by William Frost

Reginald Agbo for invaluable help talking to the farmers, not just in translation.  Luke Angleere for assistance during the interviews and Catherine Moss for valuable feedback.  This is an output from DFID, Natural Resources System Programme research project R7516 Bridging Knowledge Gaps between Soils Research and Dissemination in Ghana. The views expressed are not necessarily those of DFID.

To enable identification of requirements for interventions for participatory technology development. To address constraints brought about by declining soil fertility because of shortening bush fallows.
Individual and group interviews, PRA methods were used such as scored causal diagramming and participatory mapping.
Kyereyase and Gogoikrom, Atwima district, Ashanti region, Ghana.

Land use and livelihoods at Gogoikrom (Atwima, district)   These diagrams are simple illustrations of elements of land use and income generating activities at Gogoikrom.                                                                                                        Further information about livelihoods and farming at Gogoikrom can be found in  Frost, W. 2000.  Farmers' knowledge of soil fertility and weed management in Atwima district, Ghana: The implications for participatory technology development. Unpublished MSc. Thesis. University of Wales, Bangor. 91 pp. and   Obiri-Darko, B., Ayisi-Jatango, J., Anglaaere, L., Cobbina, J., Moss, C., McDonald, M., Sinclair, F., and Young, Einir., 2000.  Livelihood systems and farmers ecological knowledge in Ghana: a report on three districts. Shortened Bush-fallow Rotations for Sustainable Livelihoods in Ghana (DFID Project R7446). School of Agricultural and Forest Sciences University of Wales, Bangor, U.K.

memos.content: A small group interview took place with farmers who were chosen due to their level of knowledge. During the interview a causal diagram was constructed.
